prompt:
Analyze this diagnostic report:

SMART Status:
- Disk 0 (Samsung 980 Pro 1TB): GOOD
- Disk 1 (WD Blue 2TB): CAUTION - Reallocated Sector Count: 48, Current Pending Sector: 2
- Disk 2 (Seagate Barracuda 4TB): GOOD

No device manager errors.
Network: All adapters connected.
expected: The WD Blue disk shows early signs of wear with 48 reallocated sectors and 2 pending sectors. This indicates the disk is beginning to fail. Recommend: 1) Backup important data immediately, 2) Monitor SMART values weekly, 3) Plan for replacement within 3-6 months.

prompt:
URGENT: Analyze this diagnostic:

SMART Status:
- Disk 0: FAILING
  - Reallocated Sector Count: 1247
  - Current Pending Sector: 89
  - Uncorrectable Sector Count: 34
  - Power-On Hours: 52,000

Event Log:
- Disk: The device has a bad block (x47 in last 24h)
- NTFS: The file system structure on disk is corrupt
expected: CRITICAL: This disk is actively failing and data loss is imminent. The high reallocated sectors (1247), pending sectors (89), and uncorrectable sectors (34) combined with filesystem corruption indicate severe hardware failure. IMMEDIATE ACTIONS: 1) DO NOT write any new data, 2) Perform emergency backup of critical files NOW, 3) Replace the disk immediately, 4) Run chkdsk /r only after backup is complete.

prompt:
Analyze USB diagnostic:

Device Manager:
- USB Mass Storage Device: Code 43 (device reported a problem)
- Unknown Device: Code 28 (drivers not installed)

Event Log:
- USB device not recognized (x12 in last hour)
- Power surge on hub port
expected: Two USB issues detected: 1) Code 43 on mass storage suggests hardware malfunction or driver corruption - try different port, reinstall drivers, or replace device. 2) Unknown device needs driver installation - check Device Manager for hardware ID and find appropriate drivers. The power surge warning indicates possible port damage or device drawing too much power.

prompt:
Network diagnostic:

Adapters:
- Intel Wi-Fi 6 AX201: Connected, 574 Mbps, Signal: Excellent
- Realtek PCIe GbE: Media disconnected
- Hyper-V Virtual Ethernet Adapter: Connected
- vEthernet (WSL): Connected

DNS: 8.8.8.8 responding (12ms)
Gateway: 192.168.1.1 responding (1ms)
Internet: Connected
expected: Network configuration is healthy. Wi-Fi connected at 574 Mbps with excellent signal. Ethernet disconnected is normal if no cable attached. Hyper-V and WSL virtual adapters are properly configured for virtualization. DNS and gateway responding normally.

prompt:
Network diagnostic - user reports slow internet:

Adapters:
- Intel Wi-Fi 6: Connected, 72 Mbps (expected 1200 Mbps), Signal: Poor
- Realtek Ethernet: Disabled by administrator

DNS: 8.8.8.8 timeout after 5000ms
Gateway: 192.168.1.1 responding (450ms, high latency)
Packet Loss: 15%
expected: Network issues identified: 1) Wi-Fi speed degraded to 72 Mbps (should be ~1200 Mbps) with poor signal - move closer to router or check for interference. 2) DNS timeout indicates possible ISP issues or DNS server problems - try alternative DNS (1.1.1.1). 3) High gateway latency (450ms) and 15% packet loss suggest router overload or network congestion. Recommendations: Check router placement, restart router, test wired connection if Ethernet available.

prompt:
WSL Diagnostic:

WSL Version: 2.3.26.0
Distributions:
- Ubuntu-24.04: Running, Memory: 4.2 GB
- docker-desktop: Running, Memory: 2.1 GB
- docker-desktop-data: Running

vEthernet (WSL): Connected, 10 Gbps
Docker Desktop: Running
.wslconfig: memory=8GB, processors=4
expected: WSL2 environment is healthy and properly configured. Ubuntu 24.04 running with reasonable memory usage. Docker Desktop integration active with all required components. Network adapter connected at 10 Gbps (internal virtual speed). Configuration limits memory to 8GB and 4 processors, which is appropriate for development workloads.

prompt:
WSL Diagnostic - user reports WSL not starting:

WSL Version: 2.0.14.0 (outdated)
Distributions:
- Ubuntu-22.04: Stopped (error: 0x80370102)

Hyper-V: Disabled
Virtualization: Not enabled in BIOS
Windows Features: Virtual Machine Platform: Disabled
expected: WSL2 cannot start because virtualization is not enabled. Required fixes: 1) Enter BIOS/UEFI and enable Intel VT-x or AMD-V virtualization, 2) Enable Windows features: 'Virtual Machine Platform' and optionally 'Windows Hypervisor Platform', 3) Update WSL with 'wsl --update' (current version 2.0.14.0 is outdated), 4) Restart computer after changes.

prompt:
GPU Diagnostic:

GPUs:
- NVIDIA RTX 4090: OK, Driver 566.14
- Intel UHD 770: OK, Driver 31.0.101.5186

CUDA: 12.9 installed
NVML: Available
Tensor Cores: Detected (sm_89)

VRAM Usage: 2.1 GB / 24 GB
GPU Temperature: 42°C (idle)
expected: GPU configuration is excellent for AI/ML workloads. RTX 4090 detected with current driver and CUDA 12.9 support. Tensor cores available (sm_89 compute capability). Low VRAM usage and temperature indicate idle state. System is well-suited for local LLM inference with full GPU acceleration.

prompt:
Memory Diagnostic:

Physical Memory:
- Total: 64 GB DDR5-5600
- Available: 8.2 GB
- Committed: 71.4 GB / 73.6 GB

Top Processes:
- Docker Desktop: 12.4 GB
- Visual Studio: 8.7 GB
- Chrome (48 tabs): 11.2 GB
- WSL2: 8.0 GB
- Other: 15.5 GB

Page File: 18.4 GB used
expected: System is under significant memory pressure with only 8.2 GB available from 64 GB. High commit charge (71.4 GB) indicates heavy paging. Recommendations: 1) Close unused Chrome tabs (48 tabs using 11.2 GB), 2) Consider limiting WSL2 memory in .wslconfig, 3) Docker containers may need optimization, 4) Restart Visual Studio to clear memory leaks. If this is normal workload, consider adding more RAM.

prompt:
Full System Diagnostic:

Device Manager: No errors
SMART Status: All disks GOOD
Network: All adapters connected, no issues
USB: All devices functioning
GPU: NVIDIA drivers current
Memory: 32 GB available / 64 GB total
CPU: Idle 5%, Temperature 38°C
WSL2: Running normally
Docker: Healthy
expected: System is in excellent health with no issues detected. All hardware functioning properly, temperatures normal, plenty of available memory, and all services running correctly. No action required.
